The popular location, M Street is full of shops, cafes, and restaurants, and if that's not enough George Washington University is within walking distance, as well as the beautiful waterfront to the Potomac River.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tons of Opportunities – You're in Washington D.C. If you're bored you are not trying hard enough. If you don't find something to do on campus take a few steps outside the gates and hit up M street, Wisconsin street, and the GUTS buses will take you to the hotspots of Dupont and Rosslyn (where you can access the metro easily.) You can get involved with human rights campaigns on any topic and get involved with really any extracurricular. I did fencing and cognitive science club, for instance.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Living and loving and loving but living the life of love on the way to love en route to living.  Love
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Campus Aesthetics – The front end of campus is absolutely gorgeous in Flemish Gothic style you find in buildings like Healy Hall, Copley, and White-Gravenor.  However, there was a period of time where the university got away from the old stone buildings that make the campus so beautiful and began to use brick.  The result is a pretty confused campus.  and the architecture of the main Library is awful concrete.  However, the University is getting back to its roots in gorgeous new stone Business School Building and the recently constructed science building.  overall, incredible school.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: 100% Wireless Is Almost Here – Georgetown didn't have 100% wireless coverage on campus for years because it was wired for ethernet, which took second place to wireless access as the first choice of students.  So over the last 2 years, the University has been increasing wireless coverage.  It should be at 100% coverage in a year or so.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Always Better on a Sunny Day. Spring time is better because it starts off with snow, turns into cherry blossom petals, and ends with gorgeous summer weather.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Two Words: GUTS Bus – The GUTS buses are useful because they get you to the otherwise inaccessible metro stops. Otherwise, it's not too long a distance to walk to M St or Wisconsin Ave to catch other bus transportation, and taxis pass around the campus borders often.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Pretty Bad but Not Always Necessary – If you're willing to pay the $10 for the parking garage under the Southwest Quad, it's really not so bad. Just don't go searching for parking anywhere else. It takes a maximum of 15minutes to get from one extreme on campus to the other so take this option. If you try to park on the streets outside the front gates, good luck! If you can avoid using your car, it's a better idea to use public transportation to get to the school.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: In the spring, it rains quite a bit here, but it's never a hindrance to campus life.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It is pretty much expected that all students have a personal computer,especially in the business school. Fortunately, the business school has a few computers students can share as well as free printing but other schools do not have access to such resources. Another disadvantage is that although the main buildings have wireless, many dorms and certain buildings do not.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Georgetown offers its students the best of both worlds because it is located within an fun college town but also contains a campus. Locals are extremely friendly, although some neighbors may not be too nice if you have a party house. Campus is safe but walking home alone at night is not the best idea if you live off campus
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Diversity Is More Than Just a Word – All of the students are obviously unique and no one fits a stereotype. There are programs in place that would seem to be cheesy or sappy, but in reality they're just interesting and enlightening. You can learn a lot about the world without ever leaving campus (although, because you're in DC, you might want to :)
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Campus Aesthetics Gorgeous – You hardly feel like you're living in a city, it's relatively quiet, there are trees and green space, lots of gorgeous old buildings and well-kept landscaping.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
Ihealth, SFS, DC and More!!! Georgetown is one of two schools in the US that has an international health major for undergrads. "The department's curriculum blends public health and health systems management with an emphasis on the environment, culture, economics, and politics and their influence on health." 
Georgetown is also known for it's School of Foreign Service (Bill Clinton graduated from it). It's pretty self explanatory. It's a sweet school with so many opportunities available.
Georgetown also has the largest presence of interns on Capital Hill (yes even more than Harvard). The networking opportunities are limitless and even if you are not interested in politics many national organizations have their headquarters in DC. Plus there is no other city like DC and if you're going to go to school then Georgetown is the best choice.
While Georgetown may not have the title of an Ivy League (we have been offered multiple times but have declined because we would have to give up our Jesuit identity/philosophy and Big East status) we have the academics to compete with the top and sports teams that could easily beat out any Ivy League school.
Model UN is huge here!!!! We host the largest high school conference in the nation, bringing in students from all over the nation and world. Our traveling time also consistently wins awards at multiple Model UN conferences beating out other top ranking universities. 

Georgetown is seriously just the place to be. If you don't believe me, then come visit and let us prove it to you!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I have a laptop (strongly recommend one. you can find great deals for students during the summer). The computers I have seen seem to be pretty up to date and nice. The only thing that annoys me is the lack of wireless all around campus especially in the dorms. We're suppose to get it by next year though...hopefully!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Richest Neighborhood in DC – Georgetown is an extremely rich area. The least attractive townhouse may go for $1.5 million. Mst has some of the most expensive boutiques and shops in the city. There are politicians and former CEOs who live blocks away. Every president except Bush has eaten at the famous 1789 restaurant which is two blocks from the front gates. Because of its status, Georgetown is also extremely safe. The DPS updates the campus community about any offenses that occur in the area. I feel completely comfortable walking through the area (except maybe in the middle of the night but that's pretty much how it goes anywhere). Georgetown is really its own little world that is easy to get sucked into. Don't forget to venture out into the city. My favorite places are a bus ride away!!!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Metro, What Metro? There is no metro stop close to Georgetown, unlike most city schools. To get to the nearest metro, you have to take the GUTS bus - a Georgetown operated shuttle - which isn't bad. Once you get to a metro, you can basically go anywhere in the city. Taxis are pricey but available. Don't expect to find parking anywhere on campus. In terms of long distance transportation, BoltBus, Megabus, and Amtrak are the way to go.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: As I said before, it is very difficult to find parking, and it is expensive as well.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lovely Green Lawns – The lawns are perfect for playing football, catch, and frisbee. It's also a perfect place to get your suntan on; great for relaxation; and, when you find a shaded area, its awesome for studying.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Georgetown's location in DC is unbeatable. We are in the heart of the political world here, and there are always interesting things going on. With that in mind, we have excellent political-based programs, like the School of Foreign Service.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The weather in DC is very up and down. It goes from hot and humid to freezing and snowy. There also many beautiful days in fall and spring.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Safety is not much of a concern, I haven't not had any problems.  People tend to carry on about their own business.  Also, people tend to be very preppy.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The facilities at Georgetown are great overall. While some buildings are old each is equipped well. The athletic facilities are exceptional there are multiple feilds, a great gym, tennis courts, and practice space all available for students to use.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Youre Required to Bring a Laptop – Students in the business school are required to have windows computers. There is an apple lab on campus and there are computers available in the library, leavey center, and many other places around campus. Most dorms do not have wi-fi but the school does provide every student with an adapter to connect you to the school's internet system.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Georgetown is the only university in DC that doesn't have a stop on the metro but there are shuttles that take you to the 2 closest stops in DC; however, these shuttles stop running pretty early and they are unreliable on the weekends. Also, there is a public bus that runs from Georgetown to Howard and that is pretty reliable but its not free. There are other busses you can catch if you are willing to walk a little
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The on-campus parking costs a fortune and the off-campus parking will either cost you hefty fines in parking tickets or a trip to the DC DMV for a permit, both of which are undesirable.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: You'll Never Be Bored – Whether you spend time in the neighborhood of Georgetown, go into the city, or travel to nearby places such as Baltimore, there's always something to do.  The bars and clubs are popular, the museums are free, the restaurants and shops are awesome, the basketball games are exciting and everyone goes --- no matter what your style of fun is, you can always find something to satisfy it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everyone on campus has their own laptops with them. But the printers are great especially in the business school.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: O Wow...The Snowpacalypse of 2010! The weather in DC is pretty extreme for me!  I have never dealt with such unpredictable and predictable weather before.  DC weather can be dreadful - it may rain and be cloudy for an entire week, leaving you quite down.  We have had more cloudy days than sunny days.  However, it's not too cold.  It can get really sticky and gross in the spring/summer.  The only profound weather which incredibly affected my campus experience was the blizzard that hit the East coast.  We had 3 blizzards - each leaving the campus with a foot to 2.5 feet of snow.  School was shut down for 10 days (including weekends).  However, the likeliness of that happening again is rare I would think considering in past years DC gets a couple inches of snow and ice (most likely).
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: DC's a Walking City – Without the Georgetown GUTS buses I probably would never make it to the metro in winter.  That said, I love Georgetown's position away from downtown but close enough that I get to take a weekly run around the monuments (so cool!) and go out to trendy restaurants and concerts in the U Street district easily with Metrobuses, the metro, and GUTS buses.  Public transportation costs can rack up fast, but most Hoyas spend the majority of their time on campus or around Georgetown so it's not really a problem.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Yates Gym – Plenty of machines, always lots of eye-candy AND cheap classes are offered every day including dance, spinning, yoga, and core training. I love Yates, and lots of Hoyas would agree it the best way to cut the stress - especially when it's too cold to run outside.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Lord Help Washington D.C. in General – I'm probably not telling you anything you don't already know. Having a POV...military acronym...sorry. Anyway...parking is rather challenging in several areas, not to mention expensive...easy to get fined. If you are not a nontraditional person like myself who is way to accustomed to driving myself around, it will be easier for you.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: GUTS Buses Are Easy – The Transportation Shuttles that run during the week easily take you to the nearest subway station to catch an easy train. There is a public bus that stops right on campus as well.  It is not hard to get around D.C.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's a Lot Nicer Than My Previous School – DC in general is just a nicer living experience than Connecticut. It's not as warm all year as Florida, for example, but even being slightly warmer than Northeastern Connecticut is a relief.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Georgetown is better than I even imagined. The academics are very rigorous, this is not the type of school where you simply coast after very selective admissions. Curves can lead to grade deflation, but the overall academic experience is great. Generally, professors are experienced, easily accessible, and engaging. The location is unparalleled. DC is an amazing city and Georgetown is arguably the nicest part of town. Basketball games at the Verizon Center, homecoming, March Madness, and Georgetown Day bring out the huge amounts of school spirit and it's clear that the vast majority of the students absolutely love where they go to school. Socially, it's a different social experience than a lot of schools because greek life is non-existent, but that in no way harms how much fun students have. Georgetown is the quintessential college experience and the perfect balance of work and play.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: DC is an amazing city – DC is an amazing city that has lots to offer. Most museums are free. The city, and the area of Georgetown offer great food and shopping. Public transportation is easy to use and can get you anywhere in the city. On a nice day, the national mall is a 30 minute walk along the Potomac. DC also offers countless internship opportunities and most students spend at least one summer staying in DC.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I'm fairly confident that the caliber of the school will add to the value of my degree.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The resources for career development are endless. Support can be seen in every corner of the campus, with the most renowned networking opportunities available.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Being in the nation's capital gives us opportunities to many internships around the area. Additionally, because of Georgetown's prestige, there seem to be a lot more opportunities than other universities.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The alumni network is very helpful and are willing to aid students who are qualified, passionate applicants.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Now that I have formed a passion, I am confident that I will be able to get a career in that field.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's very easy to get a Job, and alumni are always willing to help.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I'm somewhat worried that I won't be as desirable without a Master's degree. Also, employers in this city have a bad habit of expecting interns to work for nothing.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: A lot of employers come to campus to recruit with many general information events to get to know the employers. The career center is also helpful in helping students find their career path and set realistic career-related goals.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Having a degree from Georgetown is definitely helpful in the job search
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The alumni network, the connections through faculty, and the name of the school itself all contribute to a solid foundation for a future career.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Employers often reach out to students on campus, and though I've never used the career center, I've heard very good things about it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: People highly respect Georgetown and the alumni network is strong. I do not know many schools with better reputations.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Just the Georgetown name on your resume will open countless doors!
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I think applying for a job with a Georgetown degree is extremely valued and highly respected. Georgetown also has a great alumni network.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Georgetown is about it's community...they take care of their own. there is a great network system that has helped many students in the past to find their dream jobs after graduation.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I'm in a top program for field, and in the program students are given the opportunity to meet working professionals and network. Also being in a small program, makes it a little more prestigious, which will look good on my resume and applications.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I am confident I will have a good job when I finish.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There is an active connect between many of the large programs in the DC area and this program at Georgetown.  Many of the pro teams and professional organizations are hiring students directly out of this program or offering them real world internships
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review:
Georgetown is very expensive. Living costs are expensive, tuition is expensive, etc. I initially applied for aid and didn't get any response, then got a very low grant from the school. After going to campus the summer before starting and talking with financial aid representatives, they were able to raise my grant a little bit and gave me work study, even working with me so that an outside scholarship I had from high school wouldn't damage my grant. However, it's still a struggle. I took out loans last year and am an RA this year, which has paid for my loans. I don't know how I'm going to pay for my senior year, as my parents and I won't really be able to afford it and likely will have to take out many loans.

Talk to the financial aid office, in person, as soon and as often as possible. The website and indirect communication with them is ineffective.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Amazing financial aid for students with demonstrated need. One of the absolute best in the country (other ivy leagues etc. model off of us - just google). However, I have heard that it can be difficult if you are just out of the range of qualifying for high aid. Work with the office, though, they are amazing.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I received really great financial aid, without it I would not have been able to come to Georgetown. The Georgetown Scholarship Program is excellent.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Theres no way around it; Georgetown is extremely expensive. The financial aid process is alright. They give what you need but not much else. DC is a very expensive city and it almost feels as if the school feels that the admission is enough.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: My financial aid was drastically cut after my freshman year because my sister graduated from college, even though my parents' income dropped from my freshman to sophomore year. Georgetown's claim that they meet all students' needs is completely false: they expect all of your parents' income to go straight to tuition, and don't keep in mind that families have other student loans, mortgages, bills, and food to put on the table. Financial aid is absolutely insubstantial.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Make sure you get information about financial aid in writing.  I had the officer tell me something and then receive something else.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Georgetown has an extremely wide range of need-based scholarships. While they do not offer any for merit, it is somewhat understandable. We are all relatively smart, and the funds should go to students who need it most.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: If you need financial aid, they will supply it to you.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: i love georgetown! hoya saxa!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: they met my full need!
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It's easy to park at the front gates
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There's a very helpful and accessible career center on campus, however, not all students proactively use this resource. We have a lot of recruiters come to campus for information sessions and interviews, though mostly in the fields of consulting, finance, and banking. If you are interested in a field that is less commonplace, it will be harder to pursue resources on campus. Georgetown has a good reputation and its name alone can open a lot of doors for internship and job opportunities.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Getting a job after college doesn't seem too difficult coming from here. There are always internship opportunities available.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a decent amount in financial aid and it was very easy to communicate with the financial aid people.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I have financial aid that fits my parents income I suppose, though I'm not an only child and it is a struggle and I know I'll have a lot of debt. Not much help for the middle class.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Georgetown has a perfect balance of everything. While it may not have the amazing tailgate scene of state schools, there are generally tons of options for nightlife, and the school is incredibly lenient about partying. Drinking is also not the only prevailing thing, so you can focus on your work when you need to. Classes may be hard, but for the most part, they're all really interesting. You may hate the workload at times, but you know you're getting a great education. There are tons of great opportunities for internships that you could never find at other schools. There is so much DC has to offer, from monuments to museums to professional sports. There is also so much going on around campus all the time- every week brings another interesting speaker or event. Athletics are fun but not overwhelming. More than anything, the people are amazing. People come from diverse backgrounds, and everyone is open to sharing their experiences with one another.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The aid I received from Georgetown was helpful in terms of funding my education, but it didn't provide anything dramatically impactful.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I've had an absolutely amazing experience at Georgetown and recommend it to all. Georgetown is full of brilliant but approachable students. Everyone is driven and generally support and help each other. Professors and employees are willing to help you.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I have no experience with financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Little to no scholarship opportunites.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: As an international students, the scholarships and grants available are extremely limited. Federal financial aid is not available to international students. Funding is a true problem and an everyday concern for me, especially since the tuition is so expensive...sometimes you can really push hard to get a small waiver on tuition but the application process includes only a handful of very competitive scholarships.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Georgetown has been incredibly generous and granted me a full-ride (including room and board) through a combination of merit and need-based scholarships.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: For international students, scholarships aren't good. In fact, I did not get any financial aid at all. I called and sent letters, but unfortunately that didn't boost my chances.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: A degree from Georgetown is something that employers do value and it probably carries the most prestige in the D.C. area.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I am struggling with trying to get more financial aid, since the school lured me with a good package the first year but has given me a worse package every year.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Fantastic alumni-network, prestigious value to our degrees, good prospects all-around.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: This process is extremely competitive and it's definitely worth looking into outside scholarships and financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: They try to help, unfortunately, it is not always successful. Georgetown is expensive and for the education you are getting its possible to see why, however, it is a lot for a family sometimes.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The process for financial aid went very smoothly. Though I wish I had more aid, the money I received is manageable.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I've had a great experience with the financial aid offices at GU.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: If you are not financially-dependent, there is no financial need for this school.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Not much available in the way of scholarships from the school for average students. I took out loans
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The paperwork is cumbersome, though no different from any other college!  I have not yet had any problem with the Financial Aid office and they stood by their promise this year to continue the aid promised me.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The financial aid is decent, but stingy in comparison to the cost of tuition.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Georgetown is not good with financial aid, plain and simple. There are some kids who get small amounts of money, but unless your family is in dire need you won't receive anything. For a big name they must not have a big endowment. Financial aid is not a huge priority for the school.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: The application process was relatively simple and easy. However, I get the distinct impression that making college affordable is not a high priority for the university.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The financial aid process for me did not go well and right now I am kind of in a predicament where I quite possibly will not be attending this school next year. I received little to no financial aid and it is painful to have to go through, no matter who you are. APPLY for scholarships!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I know several students that said the process was fairly simple for them.  While the process is simple when you carefully follow the steps, I had to resubmit documents several times and in the end I didn't receive as much aid  as I was hoping for.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Georgetown only gives scholarships based on financial need.  They make it a goal to ensure that no one should be forced not to attend based on need.  There are a lot of work-study jobs on campus.  You have to complete the FAFSA and CSS Profile to receive aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a generous financial aid package.  Contact your financial aid counselor, even go and meet them.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Georgetown is a need-blind school that is currently campaigning to increase their endowment and undergoing large construction and renovation projects. They will likely soon be able to increase the amount of available aid as well. Also, the financial aid is very good if you have real need, and the financial aid office is very helpful in navigating the process.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: About Average in My Opinion – The financial aid website is pretty informative, but I still found some minor details lacking. Also, the lack of email address to contact financial aid was inconvenient. I am sure calling will help me get the rest of my questions answered, but I like having the option of emailing so that I have a  written record of their responses.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: The Perfect Package – I received my financial aid letter together with my acceptance letter. The school offered me two scholarships which are currently paying for over 90% of tuition. The process was smooth and I have not encountered any issues with the financial aid office.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Easy Enough but Extra Forms to Watch Out for – Easy enough to fill out FAFSA, but the university also requires financial aid applications to be filled out and submitted, so keep an eye out for those deadlines as well.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It's Hard to Get Aid – Georgetown cannot give everyone financial aid, but if you really need it then Georgetown can usually help. To get scholarships is even harder, as everyone here is very distinguished and active so it's hard to stand out academically or in clubs/groups.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Its a Little Lacking – Financial aid at georgetown is a little lacking. You have to fill out both the FAFSA and CSS profile, but they don't tell you that only students with extreme need are only going to get aid. Georgetown has a pretty low endowment so middle class students get kind of screwed with the high tuition. It is worth it in the long run for the great education you get, but it is really expensive.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Mostly Great, With a Few Rare Atrocities – Almost everyone I know is happy with their financial aid.  The only thing I would say is that I got a work-study award as part of my package, but it ended up being so ridiculously small that it was basically negligible.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: IF YOU HAVE PROBLEMS, DO NOT BE SHY TO TALK TO YOUR FINANCIAL AID COUNSELOR OR GSP COUNSELOR, IF YOU HAVE ONE. I DIDN'T HAVE MONEY FOR SOMETHING AND I TOLD MY COUNSELOR, SHE IMMEDIATELY INCREASED MY SCHOLARSHIP. CLOSE MOUTHS DON'T GET FED, SO SPEAK UP. THE TUITION WITHOUT SCHOLARSHIP IS RIDICULOUS THOUGH. AROUNG 60,000 A YEAR. PEEL GRANTS HELP. LOOK FOR OUTSIDE SCHOLARSHIPS AS WELL. ITS NOT TOO LATE TO APPLY TO NEW SCHOLARSHIPS AS A SOPHOMORE OR JUNIOR EITHER, BUT IT IS EASIER TO DO IT IN HIGH SCHOOL. **ALSO, DOUBLE CHECK YOUR BILLS, THEY DO MAKE MISTAKES!!!***
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received an amazing amount of financial aid. Exactly what I needed. To my surprise, Georgetown offered me more money than my other top schools. Lots of programs created to help students. The office is extremely helpful.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Forget Merit – Everyone who gets accepted is smart enough to qualify for merit scholarships. For this reason, Gtown doesn't offer any. If you're an athlete, you stand a chance. Otherwise, forget it. We don't have the endowment.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Wish There Was More Money but at Least They Are Kind – I wasn't treated like a number and received plenty of attention but not enough money.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I got a very good amount of financial aid, but it came with a lot of work.  All of the forms took forever.  I didn't have to get any loans.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The financial aid here for me was extremely satisfactory. My school is listed on the more expensive side for universities nationwide and I received a substantial amount for the year. I would advise anyone applying to get required materials early as well as search for outside scholarships. Make sure to be in constant contact with the school's financial aid office!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They Look at Your Family Situation – In addition to the normal federal papers, gtown has you fill out extra forms that are more personal and show just how much your family can contribute. It factors in everything, including room and board AND estimated travel expenses. I've never heard anyone complain about Georgetown's financial aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I lived right across from Wisey's this year (Wisemiller's Deli) which was a blessing and a curse because I probably ate there too much. I also lived just a few blocks from Sweetgreen, which was amazing since I went there all the time. Baked and Wired has amazing cupcakes, so skip Georgetown cupcakes (which always has a huge line). Also skip Saxby's, which is more expensive than any other coffee shop around. There are a lot of options around campus, both in the neighborhood and on M street and Wisconsin, etc.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Leo's is boring and mediocre and never changes what they offer. They have a somewhat reasonable salad bar and stuff like sandwiches and nutella, and otherwise you pretty much just have to make do. However, Leo's is better than the dining halls at the school I transferred from, so I can't complain too much. The worst thing is that the meal swipes don't carry over from week to week and you can't swipe in friends.

Einstein's accepting meal swipes is a gift, although eventually you get very tired of the bagels and things that Einstein's offers. Leo's grab and go is bad, except for the breakfast during the week, which is really nice if you have an 8am lecture or something.

The fact that there is only one location for dining halls sucks, especially when it's raining or you live far away (like in LXR or Darnall).

Other campus food: Hilltoss, Vittles, and Snaxa are okay but overpriced. Corp coffee is kind of the same and the service is always very slow, although cheaper than starbucks and convenient. Epi has dollar sushi in the afternoons, but is overpriced at other times. It stays open 24 hours though, which is nice. If Hoyacourt gets meal swipes, it will be great.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: We probably have some of the best off-campus dining ever!! Just go down M or Wisconsin. Some options are a bit pricey, but others are totally reasonable. Check out your dorm lobby for coupons. There are a few places (Eat & Joy, Muncheez) that are open practically all night.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: M Street has the best options!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a ton of restaurants close to campus. Since it's D.C. some of the restaurants can be expensive. There are a a good number of late night spots to eat on the weekends.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Leo's could definitely be better, especially with the meal swipes and quality of food. There are a number of places on campus to eat besides Leo's Epicurean and Hoya Court are always good places to grab food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It cannot get much better than M street. It has everything anyone could ever want or need.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is all pretty decent. I wish meal swipes counted at every place on campus but it does not at the moment. Epi and Hoya Court are all great options but be ready to shell out some Flex Dollars. Leo's is actually a great dining hall with so many different options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Clyde's and Tombs are delicious. Chipotle is a short walking distance from the front gates and is obviously delicious.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The best available option is using a meal swipe at Einstein's. Hoya Court options like Subway are good, but unfortunately do not take meal swipes.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: They close the top floor of the dining hall on weekends, so the food selection is much more limited.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Great being in a city because there are always tons of options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Its fine.  Leos is extremely overpriced and required for two years, which is a frustrating combination.  However, positive changes have been made both at Leos, and in the addition of Hilltoss.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You are right in the middle of the Georgetown neighborhood of DC, it's easily the greatest food in the area. Many options and great taste/quality; the only issue is cost.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: No college food is going to be glamorous. The food at Leos, the dining hall, is not actually bad it is jsut repetitive. That being said, we are very lucky that we have the ability to make custom pasta bowls, custom wok, etc
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are some really great places to eat in DC, they can just be kind of pricey.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We could really use some more options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: not much variety and it's expensive
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The off-campus dining in Gtown is very expensive
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There's only one dining hall, and it's terrible. The food is not consistent at all, one day you'll eat a decent meal and the next you'll feel like throwing up. Since there is only one dining hall, it would be wise to allow students to use meal swipes in the food court and on-campus restaurant, but for some reason this is not allowed.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There aren't many options for food off-campus unless you go way off campus into another part of DC. In the vicinity of the school, options include Chipotle (a student favorite), Subway, Thai food places, salad places, a dingy Chinese food place, pizza places, and a sandwich shop or two. Despite the average quality of the food, prices are rather expensive simply because Georgetown is an expensive neighborhood.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: I dont like the on-campus dining hall so i go off campus a lot. I love the varieties I have
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Leo's is okay but not much variety so it gets tiring after a while. There are places where you can use your flex dollars but they don't last too long
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a ton of amazing places to go eat, the President even took his wife to one restaurant for her birthday once. The problem is that being in such a rich neighborhood there are a lot expensive places (though there are some good cheap spots as well)
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We are in a city so there's plenty of good places if you know where to look. Everything in Georgetown is really expensive though.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: M and Wisconsin have everything you could ever want. Specialty salad places, amazing Mexican food, Italian restuarants, Ethiopian, burger joints, pubs, high-end cuisine...everything. DC is expensive, so don't eat out too much, or you'll burn through your money in a month.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Really not as bad as people like to say it is. It's pretty standard cafeteria food. There's actually a really wide variety of things at Leo's, and if you're willing to wait in line for a while, some really good food. Leo's is a lot better than a lot of other campus cafeteria's I've visited. The most annoying thing is that other options on campus are all really expensive and for the most part don't offer meal exchange programs (use a meal swipe as payment) but that's actually changing this year- Subway, Salad Creations, and Elevation Burger should be joining Einstein Bagel in the meal exchange program.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are endless options on M Street and Wisconsin Avenue, each just blocks from campus. Most are high-quality offerings (which come with hefty prices), but there are some cheaper fast food options too. At any rate, Georgetown students do not suffer from a lack of quality off-campus dining choices.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Gets really repetitive and the food is just mediocre
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off-Campus dining is great, there are a lot of options, Georgetown is just a little pricey
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I got out of the meal plan after freshman year. The food is terrible and there are options but they are all poor options.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are quite a few options relatively close to campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: DC is a great place to eat! There are so many different options of different types of food. And the multitude of cupcake options are a great pick-me-up. Delicious! The only drawback is that it can sometimes be a bit pricey.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: If you're looking for low-cost nearby options, there are quite a few places to go–Chipotle, Shophouse, Subway, and Wisey's to name a few. If you want to go out on a classy date, there's definitely that option. If you want to explore D.C., it's really not too hard to get down to Dupont or U Street and explore what those areas have to offer.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a variety of restaurants near Georgetown University's Main campus. On a student's budget this can be quite costly but the friendships and networking are worth it! Near the Georgetown Law Center there are a few fast food places in close proximity, Union Station is two minutes away with great variety, and China Town has a lot of offerings.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Could not be happier to live at Georgetown. So many options for good food!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Campus food is quite amazing. It is privately run by a catering company. However, you do get tired of the food at one point.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The campus food is not bad. However, it is not something you really crave. It can also get very tiring.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is adequate. The options get repetative after a year or so. The employees that work at the dining hall are friendly.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: It's very difficult to find just a little bit of high-quality food.  The focus is on lots of poor-quality food.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: So many good restaurants in DC
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: As a grad student, the grad campus is terrible for on-site dining. There are plenty of options nearby though. The main campus has reasonable on-campus options, but nothing that is especially great
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: This is D.C. - we have some of the best restaurants on the east coast
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: It looks like there are many food options in the area.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Georgetown has lots of options!
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review:
Downside: there's only one dining hall, and it's located in a far corner of campus. The food is mediocre.

Upside: the dining hall is a buffet-style, privately-run establishment, which means that you can eat as much as you want and the company that runs it actually listens to your complaints and suggestions. So there's room for improvement. Also, there are a few other places to get food, such as the somewhat upscale Epicurean on the opposite side of campus, an Einstein Bros, a Cosi Cafe and the student-run convenience store Vital Vittles (which sells decent sandwiches). If you're still unsatisfied, M Street is a five minute walk away.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Plenty of restaurants on M-Street, and many more options just a metro ride away!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great variety on M Street.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Some of the places are priced high, but there are enough options that are comparable to everywhere else in the metropolitan DC area. You never run out of options and the convenience of proximity to campus and bus stops is fantastic!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The DC area's finest food is at your doorstep.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Lots of food varieties in Georgetown from very pricey to affordable.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Anyone who goes to Georgetown will tell you off campus dining is good. The reason is two-fold: the food off campus is good and convenient and the food on campus is terrible. The food off campus is pretty good but anything is better than our dining hall.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great food options, especially late-night dessert places. Definitely would not complain, though many options are incredibly expensive.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: No the best. Go out to Georgetown (the neighborrhood) you can find plenty of good restaurants there.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Lot's of variety for many different tastes/dietary restrictions. There are quite a few places popular with students
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Many off campus eateries surround the campus and they are within walking distance.  It's a once a week thing though as I can't afford the places any more than that!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: While fairly reasonably priced, the food is usually not very good but at least it's all you can eat!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Off campus dining ranges from delis and burger joints to high end restaurants (get the parents to take you to dinner when they're in town).  There are small ethnic restaurants that are rather cheap, as well as mid-range restaurants with excellent food/atmosphere and not TOO expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food on campus is good, fresh, and healthy.  More venues are being added to increase variety/options.  Like any cafeteria, the menus can be a bit monotonous.  My mother says she'd be happy if more green vegetables were available.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is only one dining hall on campus with limited options and the school makes little effort to expand your ability to use your meal swipes at other locations.  Epicurean is great, but only takes flex dollars and is definately way overpriced...
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The quality of the food is excellent. There are plenty of diverse options downtown, within walking distance from campus. The atmosphere is wonderful; however the menus are pricey, especially for students.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Within Georgetown, there are quick, inexpensive spots to grab a sandwich, but in the same neighborhood there are historic landmark restaurants as well. With plenty of variety, students are exposed to all types of food. Most sandwich shops and lunch eateries on the Hilltop accept student GOCards. I'd say the only reason I withhold the A+ is that cost is fairly expensive for students.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There are a ton, lots of ethnic food too. But GU isn't connected to the metro so you'll have to take a bus to get into real DC and extend your horizons a bit.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There's only one dining hall on campus, affectionately called Leo's. It has variety, but I wouldn't call it 5 star. Freshman year try to get the smallest meal plan, you definitely won't eat it everyday. There are food options in the student center (Leavey) and there a tons of restaurants surrounding georgetown.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review:
Georgetown has only one main dining hall, with additional restaurant and fast food options across campus (Epicurean, Subway, KFC, Pizza Hut, Starbucks, Cosi, Einstein Bros.)
Food at the main dining hall is varied with multiple stations (Italian, wok, burgers, salad bar) but is often bland or overly spiced, and when the place is at its full capacity the staff cannot handle the crowd.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There isn't much of a variety off-campus and most of them are costly. A few stay open late on the weekends, but other than that you'll have to fend for yourself.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Plenty of options on campus, an A- for slightly higher prices thorugh private companies.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Off campus dining is delicious of course, but can be expensive if you are in the Georgetown area. DC is full of different places to eat so a short trip somewhere can provide a delicious experience for little money, but you have to factor in transportation.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's only one real dining hall on campus that is way over priced in terms of individual meal prices, but Leo's does take suggestions and change depending on what the students want. There are also flex dollars that can be used at the restaurant, Epicurean, which has amazing asian food and fresh fruit. There are also good places to eat around campus, but they can be sort of expensive because of the area.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is a lot of dining in the area with excellent choices.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Every freshmen and sophomore student has to purchase a meal plan.  The food is okay but not the greatest.  If you don’t use your meals you still loss that meal.  The facilities are at least open past 10 pm.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Georgetown only has one dining hall, but it has a large variety of options and reasonably fast service. It is also all-you-can eat, and many of the people who work there are hilarious. I never have problems there, although some of my friends complain about it.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: So Many Choices – There are countless dining options on M Street and in DC in general. Whatever type of food you'd like, we have it. The only reason that this does not get an A+ is because food can be pretty expensive in the city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Easy but Pricey – Lots of restaurant and take out options. Most are great but a little expensive.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Sandwiches, Burritos and Burgers... Oh My! There's a LOT of options around campus, and the thing that's helpful is that most of these locations take GOCard money (the student ID card that's needed for access to dorms, meal plans, etc.).  Wisey's has fantastic sandwiches (especially the Chicken Madness), Q'doba offers half price dinner on Mondays, Chipotle gives Georgetown students a free drink with every meal, and Five Guys is open until 4 AM (!!) on weekends.  Wingo's has great chicken wings and fingers, and Kitchen No. 1 provides the quintessential Chinese food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Absolutely Amazing...If You Have Money – Georgetown is located just minutes from the cutesy, bustling shopping district of M Street and Wisconsin Avenue.  There are lots of adorable restaurants, ranging from Crepe Amour to Sweetgreen (salads and fro-yo), from student favorites like Wisey's and the Tombs to fancier places like 1789.  A mealtime trip to M Street can be a really fun break from Leo's, but if you're a broke student with rich friends like me, it can be a bit exasperating, because anything interesting is not really in a poor kid's budget.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: So So – there are a lot of options, but there always the same. no variety
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Amazing Variety – You can get any kind of food you want to fit any kind of budget in a very close vicinity.  Many restaurants will also deliver right to the dorms and also the academic buildings, which is very convenient.  A good option considering the dining hall is not that great and there is only one dining hall
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Gets Old Quick – Leo's is bearable if you go in with an open mind and are willing to think outside the box to create something new, you can keep it from getting boring.  It's easy to give into the off-campus temptations of Wisey's and SweetGreen, but they can add up quickly in cost.  Bottom line, don't get a huge meal plan because you won't use it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There's only one dining hall: Leo's. There are a ton of basic options (pizza, pasta, stir fry, wraps, sandwiches, soups, salads, cereal, breakfast/lunch/dinner diner food) but that's as complicated as it gets. Nothing is bad but nothing is super good either, except maybe the chicken fingers on thursdays and the french fries. You're required to have a meal plan freshman year and they're expensive, I have the 10 meal plan and living in Darnall (farthest from Leo's) I usually only use up to 8 a week. You have to get creative when making a meal. Easy to steal food to bring back to your room, grab and go option is okay (WAY healthier than all you can eat buffet at Leo's) but not worth the $10ish dollars youre paying per meal. There are block plans (such as 75 meals per semester) that are only supposed to be for upperclassmen but I plan on getting one anyways. You get relatively little flex dollars ($50 with the 10 meal plan) but there are a few Corp coffee shops that these become very useful at. Theres also a Subway thats always good and Vital Vittles is an impressive on campus grocery store. The epicurean is delicious but expensive, you'll end up paying around $8-$10 for a solid meal but its worth it if you are living in Darnall. Overall, not bad just expensive. As a freshmen, just explore all the options and discover if you really will be interested in a meal plan in future years.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The Georgetown area is one of the nicest suburbs in the entire nation. World class shopping is paired with superb cuisine options all along M Street and up Wisconsin. There is a great variety from nice places like 1789 to Chipotle to the famous Georgetown cupcake store. The area is vibrant, the restaurants are all close, and the experience of dining in Georgetown is amazing. Outside of Georgetown the entire city of DC is at your finger tips.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Way Expensive, but Mandatory – The food is fine (gets repetitive), stir fry and specialty preparations songs are good, but the staff can be very rude sometimes. 
It averages out to about 10 dollars a meal if you do the math, which is absurd, but so many students have argued it to no avail. Bring tupperware, get apples, milk it for all it's worth. You can't escape it for two years.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Many different options. All different varieties, from Italian to Indian, to your neighbor diner (Johny rockets.) No matter what you have a taste for you can find and it all in a reasonable price range.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Food at Leos is repetitive but there is a good amount of variety. However, I am a bit picky so I get tired of our dining hall food very quickly and we only have one dining hall.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: really expensive, but sometimes it's worth it to splurge.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining Options – There are a good amount of restaurants on Mst that lots of students go to. Delicious food can be found off campus or can be ordered to campus through campusfoods. The dining hall food is good although the lack of variety often has me ordering in.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining Hall Is Okay, Other Options Better. Leo's (only dining hall) is alright, food kind of gets repetitive after a while, but new things present themselves if you have your eyes open, and it prompts very creative eaters. I prefer Epicurean because I'm a sushi addict, they have great sandwiches, and the people who work there are super nice. If you get tired of these two places, Cosi and Starbucks and the student coffee shops are really snug places to kick back and eat and even study.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Anything you can think of, we've got it. There are the big, pricey places and the small, cheap shacks with the best quality food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Leo's, Leavey, and Epicurean – Creativity and resourcefulness is a must if one is going to deal with the food situation. Leo's is the only dining hall and while it is a nice atmosphere (2 floors with multiple stations) the food is sometimes less than satisfactory. Leavey has a few fast food places to eat at (Subway, Cosi, and Starbucks are normally the only one's ever open though). Epicurean is a restaurant on campus that has fairly good food but at obscene prices. In general, I recommend getting the smallest meal plan and just buying some groceries to make your own food or venture out into the city and try exotic food if you can afford it.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A Little Expensive, but Good – A lot of variety, but it is mostly expensive restaurants. You can find a few decently priced places, though.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: M Street Is Great – When you're tired of Leo's dining hall (the question is not if, it's when) check out M street for a solid variety of options. There are student-oriented places like Chipotle and Qdoba, which give great student discounts (50% off and free drinks for Georgetown students at Qdoba every monday). There are also slightly more upscale places like Tackle Box (awesome seafood), and of course various dessert spots; Georgetown Cupcake is always popular.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Not Bad After Hearing Campus Horror Stories – After always hearing from people (from different colleges) that campus food is not the best, I had pretty low expectations. I was pleasantly surprised by the food at Leo's, the dining hall. There was a ton of variety, and the food was great too!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: M Street Is the Place to Be – M Street is chock-full of great restaraunts with every cuisine from Japanese to Ethiopian.  It is great to go out with friends for special occasions. Some of my favorites are J. Paul's(a classic american saloon) and SweetGreen (a vegitarian salad shop).
Food.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It is gorgeous. They could offer more to graduate students.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is alright. Everyone gets shoved into their housing in a random system, so you might get horrible housing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Thankfully the medical housing process was not difficult and I was able to score appropriate housing for next year. Overall, the dorms are taken care of very well and located close to classes.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Like all universities, the dorms have their pros and cons. Overall, I would recommend staying on campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The housing process an be difficult and very frustrating.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The housing options on campus are alright. They are good about addressing maintenance issues.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Some dorms are gross, others are new and clean.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: My down was absolutely terrible.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing options ranges from dorms to apartments and they in generally are not brand new but livable.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Some of the apartments and dorms are in worse condition than others
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It is pretty average for college life, but because many of the buildings are old, there are many facilities issues. Also, rats and pests tend to be a problem in the apartment style housing.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Buildings are generally very nice, but nothing special.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Average college housing but excellent value considering how expensive and sought after the neighborhood is.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The housing here is no selling point.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Practically no opportunity to get out of double style dorm
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Great if you're in an apartment or townhouse, but not so much if in a dorm.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Campus housing system is pretty good compared to most universities I think. There are plenty of campus housing availability and a new dorm is currently being built. However, the three-year on-campus requirement is very difficult for most students who want to leave campus by junior year.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: You have to live on campus now for the first three years at GU. Off campus housing is really seniors-only and somewhat hard to find, start looking far in advance. Also very expensive in the Georgetown neighborhood, on-campus apartments are actually pretty similarly priced.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I came to GU as a transfer student, so I was automatically placed into LXR, which is the farthest dorm from the main campus. The rooms were more spacious than I had previously, and it was mildly annoying to have to walk 10-15 minutes to class when students on the main campus were 2 minutes away. I was on the first floor, which was incredibly loud and messy, and the fire alarm went off at all hours of the night. The price for dorms is expensive, but for on-campus apartments is somewhat more reasonable given the proximity to campus and the price of other areas in the Georgetown neighborhood. Campus housing does provide good opportunities to meet people, and community can be nice, but varies from building to building.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Many of the dorms are a little old and overpriced (rent is so high in the area). However, they are in the process of building two brand-new dorms - one opening this fall, and one opening in 2017. Those look very nice and up-to-date. The newer buildings are beautiful. Facilities is slow - you have to submit several requests for anything to really get done. Residence community is also lacking a little bit, just because everyone is so independent and there is less of an emphasis on hall activities, especially as an upperclassman. Social atmosphere is great, and can get a little crazy in some halls (New South).
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: There are a lot of houses in Burleith and in Georgetown that students can rent. However, it is now mandatory that students live on campus for 3 of their 4 years. The neighborhood isn't always a big fan of the students on the weekend. The university was here first.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms are near the class buildings. With the exception of one dorm, all of the dorms are clean and easily accessible. Georgetown has a great social atmosphere with an incredible number of clubs and social groups.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The townhouses are amazing. Georgetown is known for these houses and the kids that live in them absolutely love them. They are all close to everything.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It is a pretty awesome experience. Everything is within walking distance and you really get to know the people that are living around you. The dorms are all pretty nice compared to other college dorms that I have seen and there is a real sense of a community in a dorm building. The food on campus is great and Leo's happens to be a very popular place for people to socialize.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Good landlords are hard to find, but the opportunity to live in cute Georgetown townhouses is one of the best parts of attending the university.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Copley Hall, Village A, and Village B are all spacious and high quality housing, but could be vastly improved by basic renovation or upgrades to their amenities. Nevils is the best on-campus housing option, but is very competitive to get in the housing lottery. Options like LXR and Henle are best to be avoided, as they have rat problems and extremely low quality amenities.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Students pay huge amounts of money to live in the small but expensive townhouses near campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The buildings are old and outdated. Maintenance is also very slow and unresponsive to issues that arise frequently. Mice are a frequent problem in the apartment style housing.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Expensive if near Georgetown, but some good steals.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The Office of Residential living needs to be more transparent to the student body.  Though I have no real complaints about housing once you are already placed, Georgetown has a few changes it could make to make housing while going to Georgetown, better.  For example, the recent increase in number of years required to live on campus is making many students unhappy, especially considering they changed the policy for study-abroad students as well.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The school is pushing more and more students to live on campus, but for now there are plenty of off campus options
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Georgetown housing is far from lacking, even with its minor flaws. It is the only school I know of that includes a personal thermostat for each ROOM, even for freshmen. There are Britta filters available for each building or floor, laundry machines that do not destroy clothing, and very friendly housing staff.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's a college dorm. Not great. Not terrible. It really depends which building you get.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I have not lived off-campus, but I heard it's nice
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Living on campus is extremely convenient because classes are less than a 10 minute walk away.  The rooms are small, and usually consist of two twin beds.  The housing process is a lottery, which is okay.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing is quite overpriced for its value. Often there are maintenance and other issues that come up throughout the year, such as the stovetop not working or a toilet leaking. If you put in work order requests to maintenance, they will fix the issue sooner or later. The dorms and apartments don't really offer "amenities" but they are conveniently located by class buildings. The housing process lottery system is difficult and stressful, especially if you're an upperclassmen student who is not guaranteed housing but cannot afford off-campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing is not aided or affiliated with Georgetown's main housing office. Therefore, it is up to students to find and secure housing off-campus if they decide no to live on campus. The neighborhood of Georgetown is relatively safe, but very expensive.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is only a big thing if you plan to throw parties. Staying on campus is nice because you're close to your classes
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Worst dorm is definitely Darnall which is even more isolated than it already was because of construction, same goes for on-campus apartments Henle Village. Everything else is fairly nice and we're getting new dorms and living spaces which should be nice.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The University is currently working to get 90% of the student population on campus due to neighborhood complaints so it is a little hard to determine this category at the moment.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: You can only live off-campus senior year, as of a new rule this year. Off-campus housing is really expensive, but that's what you get when you live in a wealthy part of a big city surrounded by high-end shopping and restaurants, and the townhouses are all pretty nice, so at least you get what you pay for.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: You have to take the good with the bad when it comes to housing, at least for freshmen. Each dorm has its own unique pros and cons, and generally everyone can find things to appreciate and complain about. Nothing is extraordinary here, although I feel like we pay more for housing than students with similar amenities at other schools.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: New university policy is that only seniors can live off-campus, which is in itself a pain. Most that I know live in townhouses or apartments within a half mile or so of campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I have been lucky with housing but it overall is difficult. There are lots of option but hard to get the best.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I personally found great housing off-campus but know of many people who struggle.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I got very lucky and received an apartment as a Sophomore.  All of the Sophomore housing is ok, but the apartments stand out.  Freshmen housing is mediocre, but builds community.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Georgetown's Housing lottery really is a lottery, so how you live depends a great deal on where you live. Some of them could definitely be updated, but they're slowly in the process of doing that now. That being said, some of the "worst" dorms are the ones with the best community. I was lucky enough to be on a floor last year where almost everyone was invested in getting to know one another and we became great friends.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live in Kennedy this year, which is a decent-sized dorm. However, if you're lucky and you get an apartment, you're set for the year.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Not too well-versed on this, but I'm being required to answer, so I'll say what I do know: It's pretty expensive and you usually have to know who you want to live with one year in advance.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I am from the Caribbean and I am not looking forward to the winters so the on-campus accommodations are the highlight of my journey. I am in the center of everything, just a few strides and I am in my classroom. The amenities are amazing including a full Fitness and Wellness Gym and Subway. As to the apartments it's a comfortable easy access arrangement with concierge, 24 hours security, lovely space and great community neighbors with interesting activities.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: On-campus housing is fairly typical of a college campus. The lottery system is rather aggravating, but not necessarily worse than other campuses.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Some dorms have A/C and bathroom stalls in the room, which are extremely convenient.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The school has a mandatory 3 year policy to live on campus. So life off campus is not as popular.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is below par in general but it's very social and a great part of the Georgetown experience. Freshmen are required to live on campus at four different dorms assigned randomly. LXR is know as the social dorm with long noisy hallways and Harbin has an interest cloisters system that is more gender segregated. Upper classmen typically decide to live offcampus thir last year in over priced slums. It's the worth it to enjoy the location and the social experience.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: It's a necessity for 4th year students to live off-campus, nonetheless it's a hassle and expensive.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Not the newest and prettiest but good community
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: If you live off-campus you are pretty much living in a townhouse in Georgetown. They are really expensive, but perfect location and nice for parties. However, the universitiy is chaning policies, so that only Seniors can live off campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: This is a big city, you pay big city prices and you might have to compromise
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I could raise some minor gripes with university housing (the archaic and confusing selection process for example) but overall there's nothing here worth deterring anyone from enrolling. Every college has some new, clean, modern dorms and Georgetown is no exception. But even if your freshman dorm is less than satisfactory at first you'll soon forget about it entirely because you're surrounded by hundreds of other students in the same exact situation. No dorm is more than 7 minutes away from the farthest possible class. Many dorms are located within minutes of most of the classes you'll have.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Off campus housing in Georgetown is not only expensive but very competitive due to the wave of interns that arrive in summer. It is highly unlikely anyone is renting a 1 bedroom by themselves.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The on campus housign is bad for freshmen but for the upper years it gets a lot better.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I can't speak from personal experience, but it seems to be the case that if you want campus housing, you're on your own. Knock on a door, ask the people living there who you should call to rent the house for the following year, and let the housing office know what you choose to do. All of the townhouses I've been in are beautiful and extremely close to campus (some even closer than dorm rooms). Just know that exorbitant D.C. housing prices apply.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Students are required to live on campus until their senior year now, which some might consider undesirable. I've found the housing selection process to be a bit complicated but well-run, and the housing office is very responsive in solving any issues that may come up. As for the dorm experience itself, expect pretty cramped rooms unless you've lucked out with a low selection number. However, especially in freshman dorms, the solid floor community tends to compensate for this pretty well.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Georgetown is extremely expensive, so it's better to find a place in the suburbs a little further out for a cheaper price and commute in to class, because the rides are not bad at all. Public transportation is so easy and there is a stop right down the hill from campus so I don't think it's worth spending tons of money to live right on or next to campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing is nicer off campus, but it is too far away and the neighbors are terrible.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is hard because it is not the nicest in the world. Rooms are small, but the atmosphere in Georgetown dorms is great! I made some of my best friends because they lived in my hall my freshman year.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The specific dorm I am in is not a good dorm. It has not been renovated in many years, it is too small, and has only one perk.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There is nice housing off-campus, but the area close to the school is an expensive area.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I'm in a larger dorm this year but have stayed in a smaller room which didn't offer much space for 2 people.  My roommate is in charge of the housing process for next year since I'm in travel season.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off-campues housing is better because you can share a an apartment with other room mates and share expenses
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Being accepted to Georgetown University was the best thing ever happened to me
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: There are a lot of options, but pretty pricey the closer you are to campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I live in the freshmen party dorm on campus. It is dirty and often full of vomit and other unpleasant things, but it has a great social atmosphere for a first-year dorm.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are very nice upper classmen facilities on campus.  it is cost prohibitive to move off campus for the most part
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The off-campus housing is close to campus, classes, and shopping.  It can get pricey, but it is safe, clean and up-to-date.  Parking is limited, but public transportation is readily available as well as campus shuttles, and most places can be walked to easily.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most of the housing is older, but it's been updated and is quite comfortable and meets the needs.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: As a transfer, I've seen a lot of campuses, and Georgetown is exactly average. Housing is ok, but not great, freshman year, and as you get older you have more choices. Junior year is the best year for on campus housing; you're almost guaranteed a university owned apartment or townhouse.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review:
Housing selection is a very painless experience; the university provides lots of information about the process and tries to give students as much freedom as possible while trying to be fair to everyone. Freshmen choose roommates through CHARMS and are randomly assigned to freshmen-only dorms. Sophomore and beyond, you may apply to the lottery for certain housing options that are generally better than freshman dorms. Many people group up and apply to live together. Junior and seniors can live in campus-owned townhouses - Village A, Village B, or Henle - if they want.

The housing itself? Simple, functional, brick-walled public-school 60's/70's utilitarian. Nothing has been recently renovated apart from New South. Each dorm has its own advantages (for example, Village C West has its own bathrooms, Village A has a view, Southwest Quad dorms are in the middle of everything, Darnall Hall develops super-tight floor communities, etc.). Convenience varies, but the clustered campus makes even the walk from Darnall (no man's land) manageable. You'll see rats outside at night, but rarely in a dorm. Cleanliness is essential to keep cockroaches out.
