In summary, Georgetown dorms are fine. The differences in quality aren't that drastic (even if you get Darnall, you'll be fine, take it from a current resident). They are livable and work for everything you need from a dorm.  However, visiting your friends at GW may make you die a little inside.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Campus housing is barely inhabitable. Both dorms I have lived in have had black mold, rats, and cockroach infestations. The university will ignore your requests for fixing this, and instead of cleaning mold, will paint over it. It's a huge health hazard and embarrassing to the name of the university.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing can be lousy or awesome, and it can sincerely make or break your year. My freshman dorm was spacious and had its own bathroom (1/4 of the freshman dorm buildings have rooms with a bathroom) which was nice. However, I was unlucky because I got put on the smallest floor on campus (12 people) and it wasn't a very social atmosphere. Some of the housing is far off from everything but I have heard that you become very close to the people you live around.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off-campus housing for upperclassmen is one of the Georgetown traditions practically. The quaint and narrow houses in the Georgetown neighborhood really are just picaresque. They are often expensive, but when students get housing there they split the cost with several others making the costs affordable.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is expensive and complicated to secure with landlords because we are in an urban area.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing isn't fabulous, and it's expensive. Most dorms are far from the comforts of home and looking a bit worn.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Finding affordable, quality housing in D.C. is a well-known quagmire. It can be difficult to find housing that is reasonably close to campus as well as in a good neighborhood.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: One thing that I feel is important for underclassmen to know is that while it's possible to get on-campus housing your Senior year, it's also a little risky because it's not guaranteed. It's best to start looking around at the end of your sophomore year and sign a lease by October or even September of your Junior year to get a good off-campus house for Senior year that's reasonably priced.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing gets better as you become an upperclassman. Expect your typical dorm-style living as a freshman (hall style, shared bathrooms) but you'll look forward to living in apartments are you move up the ranks!
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Freshman and Sophomores must live on campus. Juniors and most senior live off campus.  Seniors are not guaranteed on campus housing. Houses in the Georgetown area are extremely expensive and you have to start looking early but it is worth it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Georgetown has a great atmosphere, set of students, visibility, and resources. Some areas are lacking though such as dorm facilities.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The community at Georgetown is wonderful.  There are a lot of programs and events to keep you busy and the staff is so kind a helpful.  The atmosphere depends heavily on where you live.  Some dorms are more community oriented than others.  The main issue most students have is dining.  The meal plan is rather limited and there is only one dining hall.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: So much fun. There's a tough market to find good off campus housing, but if you are willing to pay (yes, it's very expensive) then you are fine. The really nice townhouses are amazing though. Great for throwing parties and you are located in an awesome part of Georgetown with close access to everything you need including being right by campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living on campus cost a lots and having difficulties term of paying texbooks and etc
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Housing is very expensive in DC. Most of the apartments I looked at were for young professionals, which wasn't exactly the atmosphere I was looking for as a college student.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: A Lot of Variety – Georgetown's housing has a lot of variety. The freshman dorms are good in their own different ways, and upperclassman housing is great too. The new southwest quad and Copley are great, while the apartments in Henle or Village A are spacious. The townhouses are, of course, the pinnacle of housing options at any university
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Great Apartments – Provided you don't get put in LXR, Georgetown has great apartment options, like the Village A and B's.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
Freshman Dorms – I visited plenty of schools before choosing Georgetown- on average, GU has the biggest rooms. 
Darnall- nasty, away from all of the other freshman dorms, the walk to it is long and you WILL see massive rats at night along with cockroaches three times the size of normal ones. Rooms are a good size and there's plenty of storage space. No one will want to visit you though.
VCW- by far the best if you want your own bathroom! The rooms are smaller but it's because you have your own bathroom. My floor is really clean. 
Harbin: you have same sex clusters on each floor and reach cluster has a community bathroom and community showers. Rooms are big. 
New South: the party dorm. It's nasty, for the most part, and people are just incredibly loud. All of my friend who live there complain about the noise and not being able to go to sleep before 2am on weekDAYS or study in their rooms. The rooms are spacious, for the most part, and you have a sink/mirror in your room (which is awesome).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Living in DC – I live off campus this year and will be living off campus next year as well. The interesting thing about Georgetown is that you are treated like an independent adult in all interactions with the University. The same holds true for off campus housing. If you want to live off campus it is on you to search for a place. There are always tons of houses on the market with a huge price range. If you want to live in front of the University it will be very pricey but the houses are great. If you are looking for something cheaper you can live on the other side of campus in Burleith. There is a vibrant off campus life. Georgetown owns a lot of houses outside of the gates so it is hard to define 'off campus.' I rent a house with friends but I live across the street from a dorm.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Avoid Darnall – The housing options for the most part are great, with a few exceptions for some unlucky souls.  Freshman dorms have their own bathrooms for doubles, except if you live in Darnall Hall, in which case heaps of misfortune will be piled onto your helpless soul.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorms and Apartments - Solid Options – On-campus living is pretty good. Freshmen dorms are actually nice, especially compared to many other schools. Each dorm has its own feel and its own vibe. As you get older, the housing gets awesome - Village A rooftop parties and views of the city and Potomac River are gorgeous. Nevils just got redone as well with exposed brick walls and brand-new appliances.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Smaller Houses – off-campus housing may be tough to get because Georgetown is a crowded area
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
It's a Dorm – All of the Freshman dorms are typical college dorms. Loud and messy, especially on weekend nights. The rooms aren't closets, but they're not particularly spacious, either. 

Upperclassmen dorms aren't that nice, but on-campus apartments are sought after, as are university-owned town houses. Some upperclassmen opt to rent houses in nearby West Georgetown and Burleith, but rent and utilities are high and don't save students much money. The neighbors also hate Georgetown students. Unfortunately there are no cheap housing options for Georgetown students. On the bright side, because campus is so small, no one lives more than a fifteen minute walk from campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The Townhouses Are Adorable! I'm a freshman currently, and honestly I'm a bit terrified at the prospect of the upperclassmen housing lottery.  Since there is only a certain number of university-owned townhouses and Village A rooftop apartments and other coveted residences, I've heard the whole process can be a bit dramatic.  As far as I know, everyone who does live off-campus is pretty satisfied with their living situation, and the Georgetown neighborhood is relatively safe.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Beautiful but Pricey – there is a lot of student turnover in the area so you can find a place to live... if you can afford it - otherwise there are options throughout the city, but georgetown is a pain because there's no metro
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: About What You'd Expect – Freshmen live in traditional dorms (More or less what you'll get anywhere). Upperclassmen are eligible for apartment-style housing (or, still, dorms). Juniors & seniors often live off campus
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Depends on Lottery – All freshmen live in dorm rooms, but there's a generally good selection of apartments for upperclassmen as well as townhouses for those who get lucky in the housing lottery
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The town houses off-campus are really cool and often host parties. They are good if you want to distance yourself from all of the underclassmen on campus, but not get too far away. You can also rent houses in Burleith.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshmen dorms are okay, especially New South, but Darnall is awful and needs to be renovated.  On Campus townhouses and the newly renovated Nevils apartments are best for upperclassmen.  Mice are a problem in every building.  The housing lottery isn't the best.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Freshman Dorms – Overall, the dorms here are pretty nice as long as you don't get stuck with Darnall. Harbin (social and you can become close with your clustermates, awkward room layouts but big), New South (newest, big rooms with awkward layout, social but not intimate), and VCW (own bathrooms but TINY rooms) are all close together and by Leo's (the only dining hall) so its kind of a "freshman social area" where you see/run into a lot of people. BEWARE OF DARNALL: in opposite corner of campus, 10-15 walk from Leo's, small/muggy rooms with little light, disgusting bathrooms, slow elevators, stairs up to lobby/RHO, separated from rest of freshman campus. Henle (sophomore/junior apartments) is in the same location and no one complains, but thats because your friends will be all over the place as well. It sucks being left our of the 3-dorm freshman cluster, and yeah you will become noticeably closer with your floor/dorm mates than everyone else but I dont think its worth it. And you mostly bond over the fact that your dorm sucks. If you have a horrible floor, you are forced to hang out with them. My best friends are in New South and no one ever wants to come over here, also walks on the way back down alleyways/by parking garages and the hospital are dangerous/scary and cold in the winter time. Housing is random so you don't really have a choice, but there's always the option of trying to switch out if you get Darnall (which I would definitely recommend)
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Excellent Housing – Georgetown has town houses that are some of the best real estate in the country. Although they are a little pricy, the Georgetown area is invaluable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The Freshmen Dorms – Overall not bad. Having one hundred other freshman on your floor helps with meeting people. New South has sinks in the room but a shared bathroom and shower room. Other dorms can be worse or better (ex one Freshman dorm has bathrooms for each room and there is another that you have no sink or bathroom and share everything). The size isn't bad, but the closet and desk are built in and not movable so you can't do much with the set up.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Apartments are expensive.  This is unsurprising considering it is the nation's capitals and one of the most soft after neighborhoods in the city.  Most people live in Rosslyn or other DC areas for cheaper rent.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Overall, the big thing is basketball. There is also a huge number of other sports since there is a field, gym or stadium SOMEWHERE on almost every section of campus. The parking at events is murder because there is so much pride, so ALWAYS car pool. Seriously. It's can get really hyped.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Off campus housing is great. It's beautiful, spacious and extremely close by. However, the area is Georgetown so subletting etc can get costly. The federal style houses are super cute and students tend to live together with other students when living off campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Leo's Is Great – Leo O'Donovan Hall ("Leo's") is the main dining hall for students and it is excellent...no kidding.  It is routinely ranked very high for vegetarian options, and it caters to palates of all types.  No complaints...I have had a meal plan for 4 years and love it.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Pricey but Picturesque – Georgetown neighborhood townhouses are very popular for upperclassmen, though a good price and location are hard to come by. Its an expensive neighborhood but the townhouses around campus couldn't be more perfect
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Easy and Social Experience – Everyone is very open to meeting people on their floors and in their dorms. Rooms vary in size, but are not too crowded. Village C's bathrooms are really a treat. Not really a bad option location-wise- even Darnall is close to classrooms.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: First Come First Serve! Housing is not guaranteed for juniors and seniors.  So off campus housing is needed in some situations (not many). If you are looking to get a "house" in the immediate Georgetown area, you'll need to sign a lease probably around October for the following fall. They go quickly. Avoid the dangerous Burleith.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Usually Small, and Often You Will Find Rats – Some of the dorms have been recently renovated, such as New South, Village A, and Darnall... but they are all pretty small - even the upper classmen apartments. And there are lots of rats...
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The best dorms for underclassmen are Village C and New South.  The worst would be Darnell. But it is being currently renovated.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The area around Georgetown University is called Georgetown and that are is very expensive to live. In fact, it is the most expensive part in DC, but it is not that much more expensive than living on campus (but there's no financial aid of course lol). If you have a car then you can get a decently priced apartment in another part of the city , but only if you have a car because public transportation is defintely a problem when it comes to gtown
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I have not yet had to deal with off-campus housing, but it is extremely inconvenient that GU does not guarantee on-campus housing your junior and senior year and that obviously because it is DC, living off-campus is pricey.  Some areas are 15 minutes away from campus but it still is unfortunate if you are like 99% of the campus and are involved in 100 activities.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Cheap but Poor Quality – Housing off campus is relatively cheap for DC prices however, the conditions of the houses are usually poor.  You will have several roommates and will often deal with unfriendly landlords.  Off-campus housing is easy to find and is close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Recommend Older Students Live Off Campus – As a nontraditional student who has lived independently for several years, it is quite challenging finding your own abode on campus. Once you find something though, very nice!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore
